folies de galanterie
Dans leur Monde
target_segments: the Countess
amorous Follies
In his own World or Sphere
explanations: The original French uses the pronoun "elle" (she), referring to the character of the Marquise, a specific French aristocratic title. The English translation renders this as "the Countess." This change substitutes the French aristocratic title of "Marquise" (implied by "elle" referring to the character described in the work's background) with "Countess," a noble title perhaps more common or readily understood within the English social hierarchy of the late 17th century compared to "Marchioness" (the direct English equivalent of Marquise). This makes the character's rank more aligned with English societal structures, a form of domestication by replacing a culture-specific reference with a target culture near-equivalent perceived as more accessible.

The French phrase "folies de galanterie" refers to playful, witty, and often light-hearted flirtatious interactions characteristic of French salon culture and 17th-century notions of refined courtship. The English translation "amorous Follies" shifts the emphasis towards more direct romantic or sexual desire ("amorous"). This adaptation simplifies the nuanced French concept of "galanterie," potentially making it more straightforwardly intelligible or aligning it with English literary or social conventions for depicting such interactions, thereby domesticating a culturally specific mode of behavior.

The French "Dans leur Monde" (In their World), referring to the realm or system of a sun within its Cartesian vortex, is translated as "In his own World or Sphere." The addition of "or Sphere" domesticates Fontenelle's terminology. In 17th-century English, "sphere" was a common and resonant term in astronomical and cosmological discussions (e.g., celestial spheres, sphere of influence). By adding "or Sphere," the translator links "Monde" to this familiar English concept, potentially making Fontenelle's idea more accessible or aligning it more closely with the target audience's existing conceptual framework for understanding cosmic structures.

chunks.source_manual: <P092>Assurément, repris-je, mais la difficulté est de deviner. Que sçay-je? Un Tourbillon a plus de Planetes qui tournent autour de son Soleil, un autre en a moins. Dans l'un il y a des Planetes subalternes, qui tournent autour des Planetes plus grandes; dans l'autre il n'y en a point. Icy elles sont toutes ramassées autour de leur Soleil <UP></UP>, & font comme un petit peloton, au-delà duquel s'étend un grand espace vuide, qui va jusqu'aux Tourbillons voisins; ailleurs elles prennent leur cours vers les extremitez du Tourbillon & laissent le milieu vuide. Je ne doute pas mesme qu'il ne puisse y avoir quelques Tourbillons deserts, & sans Planetes, d'autres dont le Soleil, n'estant pas justement au centre, ait un veritable mouvement, & emporte ses Planetes avec soy; d'autres dont les Planetes s'élèvent ou s'abaissent à l'égard de leur Soleil par le changement de l'équilibre qui les tient suspenduës. Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez pour un homme qui n'est jamais sorty de son Tourbillon.</P092>
chunks.target_manual: <P072>It is certainly true, said I; but the difficulty is to know wherein they differ. One Vortex hath many Planets that turn round about its Sun; another Vortex hath but a few: In one Vortex, there are inferiour or less Planets, which turn about those that are greater; in another perhaps, there are no inferiour Planets; here, all the Planets are got round about their Sun, <UP>in form of a little Squadron</UP>; beyond which, is a great void space, which reacheth to the neighbouring Vortex's: In another place, the Planets take their course towards the out side of their Vortex, and leave the middle void. There may be Vortex's also quite void, without any Planets at all; others may have their Sun not exactly in their Centre; and that Sun may so move, as to carry its Planets along with it: others may have Planets which in regard of their Sun, ascend and descend, according to the change of their Equilibration, which keeps them suspended. But I think I have said enough for a Man that was never out of his own Vortex.</P072>
source_segments: un petit peloton
Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez
target_segments: a little Squadron
But I think I have said enough
explanations: The French "un petit peloton" literally translates to "a little ball" (like a ball of yarn) or more generally "a small, tight cluster" or "a small group/huddle." This imagery is common and somewhat informal. The English translation replaces this with "a little Squadron," which in the late 17th century primarily referred to a military or naval formation. This substitution is a domestication because it adapts the original metaphor to one that might have resonated more strongly or seemed more appropriately ordered to an English audience of the period, particularly given Britain's rising naval power. It shifts the imagery from a general, possibly softer cluster to a more formal, organized, and potentially martial arrangement, aligning with target culture sensibilities regarding order and perhaps even power.

The French phrase "Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez" conveys a meaning like "Finally, what more could you want/expect? That's quite enough of it..." It features a direct and somewhat playful rhetorical question ("que voudriez-vous?") characteristic of an engaging French conversational style. The English translation, "But I think I have said enough," transforms this into a more straightforward and somewhat subdued declarative statement. This is an instance of domestication because it smooths out a distinctly French conversational idiom and rhetorical flourish, replacing it with a more conventional English way of concluding a point. This adaptation makes the philosopher's tone align more closely with potentially more reserved English conversational norms of the era, reducing the "foreignness" of the interaction for the target reader.

chunks.source_manual: <P093>Ce n'en est guere, répondit-elle, pour la quantité des Mondes. Ce que vous dites ne suffit que pour cinq ou six, & j'en voy d'icy des milliers?</P093>
chunks.target_manual: <P073>It is not so much, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, considering what a multitude of Worlds there are; what you have said is sufficient but for five or six, and <UP>from hence I see thousands</UP>.</P073>
source_segments: elle
target_segments: the Countess
explanations: The original work by Fontenelle features dialogues between a philosopher and a 'Marquise.' In the provided French segment, 'répondit-elle' means 'she replied,' where 'elle' (she) refers to this Marquise. The English translation renders this phrase as 'reply'd the Countess,' specifically substituting 'elle' with 'the Countess.' This is an instance of domestication because 'Countess' is not the direct English equivalent of the French 'Marquise' (which would be 'Marchioness') and represents a different, slightly lower, rank in the peerage system. The translator likely chose 'Countess' as a title that would be more familiar, common, or representative of an educated noblewoman to the English readership of the late 17th or early 18th century. This adaptation makes the character more aligned with target culture expectations or archetypes, thereby potentially increasing accessibility, but at the cost of altering the specific social standing attributed to the character in the source text.

chunks.source_manual: <P094>Que serait-ce donc, repris-je, si je vous disois qu'il y a bien d'autres Etoiles Fixes, que celles que vous voyez; qu'avec des Lunettes on en découvre un nombre infiny qui ne se montrent point aux yeux, & que dans une seule Constellation, où l'on en comptoit peut-estre douze ou quinze <RW></RW>, il s'en trouve autant que l'on en voyoit <UP></UP> auparavant dans tout le Ciel?</P094>
chunks.target_manual: <P074>What, Madam, would you say, if I should tell you, there are many more fix'd Stars than those you see? and that an infinite number are discover'd with Glasses, which never shew'd themselves to our Eyes: In only one Constellation, where it may be, we count twelve or fifteen, there are as many to be found as usually appear in the whole Hemisphere.</P074>
source_segments: l'on en voyoit auparavant dans tout le Ciel
target_segments: usually appear in the whole Hemisphere
explanations: The French source text 'l'on en voyoit auparavant dans tout le Ciel' (one previously saw in the whole sky) refers to the total number of stars known or visible across the entire celestial sphere before the advent of telescopes. The English translation 'usually appear in the whole Hemisphere' changes this baseline. 'The whole Hemisphere' reduces the scope from the entire celestial sphere to half of it (the portion visible to an observer at one time). Furthermore, the phrase 'usually appear' shifts the meaning from a general or historical count (what 'one saw before', potentially including all catalogued stars) to what is commonly or typically visible to an individual observer. This adaptation grounds the comparison in the immediate, experiential reality of the target reader (e.g., the Marquise), making the philosopher's statement more relatable and perhaps aligning with a perceived preference in English popular science for empirical or observation-based framing for a lay audience. This is a domestication as it adapts the concept to target culture norms of understanding and accessibility, potentially at the cost of the original's broader astronomical scale.

chunks.source_manual: <P095>Je vous demande grace, s'écria-t-elle, je me rends, vous m'accablez de Mondes & de Tourbillons. Je sçay bien, ajoûtay-je, ce que je vous garde ancore. Vous voyez cette blancheur qu'on appelle la Voye de Lait. Vous figureriez-vous bien ce que c'est? Une infinité de petites Etoiles invisibles aux yeux à cause de leur petitesse, & semées si prés les unes des autres qu'elles paroissent former une blancheur continuë. Je voudrois que vous vissiez avec des Lunettes cette Fourmilliere d'Astres, & cette graine de Mondes (si ces expressions sont permises.) Ils ressemblent en quelque sorte aux Isles Maldives, à ces douze mille petites Isles ou Bancs de Sable, separez seulement par des Canaux de Mer, que l'on sauteroit presque comme des Fossez. Ainsi les petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait sont si serrez, qu'il me semble que d'un Monde à l'autre on pourroit se parler, ou mesme se donner la main. Du moins je croy que les Oyseaux d'un Monde passent aisément dans un autre, & que l'on y peut dresser des Pigeons à porter des Lettres comme on fait icy dans le Levant. Ces petits Mondes sortent apparemment de la regle generale, par laquelle un Soleil dans son Tourbillon efface dés qu'il paroist tous les Soleils étrangers. Si vous estes dans un des petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait, vostre Soleil n'est presque pas plus proche de vous, & par consequent n'a pas sensiblement plus de force sur vos yeux, que cent mille autres Soleils des Tourbillons voisins. Vous voyez donc vostre Ciel briller d'un nombre infiny de feux, qui sont fort proches les uns des autres, & peu éloignez de vous. Lors que vous perdez de veuë vostre Soleil particulier, il vous en reste encore assez, & vostre nuit n'est pas moins éclairée que le jour, du moins la diference ne peut pas estre sensible, & pour parler plus juste, vous n'avez jamais de nuit. Ils seroient bien étonnez, les Gens de ces Mondes-là, accoûtumez comme ils sont à une clarté perpetuelle, si on leur disoit qu'il y a des malheureux qui ont de veritables nuits, qui tombent dans des tenebres tres-profondes, & qui quand ils joüissent de la lumiere, ne voyent mesme qu'un seul Soleil. Ils nous regarderoient comme des Estres disgraciez de la Nature, & fremiroient de l'horreur de nostre condition.</P095>
chunks.target_manual: <P075>I submit, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, and beg your pardon: You quite confound me with Worlds and Vortex's. I have yet more to tell you, Madam, said I: You see that whiteness in the Sky, which some call the milky way; Can you imagine what that is? 'Tis nothing but an infinity of small Stars, not to be seen by our Eyes, because they are so very little; and they are sown so thick, one by another, that they seem to be one cotinu'd whiteness: I wish you had a Glass, to see this Ant-hill of Stars, and this Cluster of Worlds, if I may so call 'em: They are in some sort, like the Maldivian Islands: those twelve thousand banks of Sand, separated by narrow Channels of the Sea, which a Man may leap as easily, as over a Ditch: So near together are the Vortex's of the Milky way, that the People in one World, may talk, and shake Hands with those of another; at least I believe, the Birds of one World, may easily fly into another; and that Pigeons may be train'd up to carry Letters, as they do in the Levant. These little Worlds are excepted out of that general Rule, by which one Sun in his own Vortex, as soon as he appears, effaceth the light of all other forreign Suns: If you were in one of these little Vortex's of the Milky way, your Sun would not be much nearer to you, and consequently, would not make any much greater sensible impression on your Eyes, than a hundred thousand other Suns of the neighbouring Vortex's: You would then see your Heaven shine bright with an infinite number of Fires, close to one another, and but a little distant from you; so that tho' you should lose the light of your own particular Sun, yet there would still remain visible Suns enough beside your own, to make your Night as light as Day, at least, the difference would hardly be perceiv'd, for the truth is, you would never have any Night at all: The Inhabitants of these Worlds accustom'd to perpetual Brightness, would be strangely astonish'd, if they should be told that there are a miserable sort of People, who where they live, have very dark Nights, and when 'tis Day with them, they never see more than one Sun; certainly they would think Nature had very little kindness for us, and would tremble with horrour, to think what a sad condition we are in.</P075>
source_segments: s'écria-t-elle
comme on fait icy dans le Levant
vostre Ciel
des Estres disgraciez de la Nature
target_segments: says the Countess
as they do in the Levant
your Heaven
Nature had very little kindness for us
explanations: The original character is a 'Marquise'; the translation of 's'écria-t-elle' (she cried/exclaimed) as 'says the Countess' substitutes the Marquise with a 'Countess,' a noble title arguably more common or familiar within the English societal context of the period, thus domesticating the character by adapting her title to target culture norms.

The French 'icy' (here) in 'comme on fait icy dans le Levant' grounds the practice of using carrier pigeons in the speaker's (French/European) world; the translation 'as they do in the Levant' removes this local, source-culture tie and changes 'on fait' (one/we do) to 'they do', presenting the practice as more distant and solely Levantine, thus domesticating by generalization to reduce foreignness.

Translating the astronomical 'Ciel' (sky) as 'Heaven' introduces stronger religious connotations common in English parlance for the cosmos, aligning Fontenelle's scientific discourse with the religiously-infused language of the 17th-century English target culture, potentially tempering the work's secular scientific perspective as described in the cultural context.

The stark French philosophical phrase 'des Estres disgraciez de la Nature' (beings disgraced by Nature) is significantly softened to the understated 'Nature had very little kindness for us,' domesticating a potentially unsettling or philosophically bold concept by reducing its original intensity to make it more palatable or align with possibly more moderate target culture sensibilities.

chunks.source_manual: <P096>Je ne vous demande pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, s'il y a des Lunes dans les Mondes de la Voye de Lait; je voy bien qu'elles n'y seroient de nul usage aux Planetes principales qui n'ont point de nuit, & qui d'ailleurs marchent dans des espaces trop étroits pour s'embarrasser de cet attirail de Planetes subalternes. Mais sçavez-vous bien qu'à force de me multiplier les Mondes si liberalement, vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté? Les Tourbillons dont nous voyons les Soleils, touchent le Tourbillon où nous sommes. Les Tourbillons sont ronds, n'est-il pas vray? Et comment tant de Boules en peuvent-elles toucher une seule? Je veux m'imaginer cela, & je sens bien que je ne le puis.</P096>
chunks.target_manual: <P076>I do not ask you, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, whether in those Worlds of the Milkyway, there be any Moons; I see they would be of no use to those principal Planets which have no Night, and move in spaces too strait and narrow to cumber themselves with the baggage of inferiour Planets: Yet pray take notice, that by your liberal multiplication of Worlds, you have started an objection, not easily answer'd: The Vortex's whose Suns we see, touch the Vortex in which we are, and if it be true, that Vortex's are round, how then can so many Bowls or Globes all touch one single one? I would fain imagine how this may be done, but cannot think which way.</P076>
source_segments: Marquise
vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté
Boules
je sens bien que je ne le puis
target_segments: Countess
you have started an objection, not easily answer'd
Bowls or Globes
cannot think which way
explanations: The French title "Marquise" is replaced by the English noble title "Countess." While both denote high nobility, they are specific to their respective aristocratic systems. The translator chose an English equivalent to make the character's social standing more immediately recognizable and relatable to an English audience of the time, thereby domesticating the foreign social hierarchy by using a familiar English social rank.

The French phrase "vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté" (literally, "you make a true difficulty be born for me") employs a subtle metaphor. The English translation, "you have started an objection, not easily answer'd," replaces this with a more direct and somewhat formal English construction ("started an objection") and adds an emphatic clause ("not easily answer'd"). This domestication adapts the French metaphorical idiom to a more conventional target language phrasing for introducing a complex point or problem, aligning with English rhetorical norms.

The French "Boules" (balls/spheres) is translated as "Bowls or Globes." While "Globes" is a direct equivalent for spheres, the addition of "Bowls" likely refers to the spherical balls used in the game of bowls, a popular pastime in England. This introduces a familiar, culturally resonant image for English readers to visualize the spherical nature of the Cartesian "Tourbillons" (Vortex's), thus domesticating the abstract scientific concept by grounding it in a common cultural reference.

The French phrase "je sens bien que je ne le puis" (literally, "I feel well that I cannot do it" or "I am well aware I cannot"), expressing a general inability to comprehend or visualize, is translated into the more specific and idiomatic English expression "cannot think which way." This adaptation aligns the speaker's articulation of her difficulty with common English conversational patterns for expressing cognitive bewilderment, making her speech sound more natural and familiar to the target audience by using a standard English idiom.

chunks.source_manual: <P097>Il y a beaucoup d'esprit, répondis-je, à avoir cette difficulté-là, & mesme à ne la pouvoir résoudre; car elle est tres-bonne en soy, & de la maniere dont vous la concevez, elle est sans réponse, & c'est avoir bien peu d'esprit que de trouver des réponses à ce qui n'en a point. Si nostre Tourbillon estoit de la figure d'un Dé, il auroit six faces plates, & seroit bien éloigné d'estre rond, mais sur chacune de ces faces on y pourroit mettre un Tourbillon de la mesme figure. Si au lieu de six faces plates, il en avoit vingt, cinquante, mille, il y auroit jusqu'à mille Tourbillons qui pourroient poser sur luy, chacun sur une face, & vous concevez bien que plus un corps a de faces plates qui le terminent au dehors, plus il <IIM>approche d'estre rond</IIM>, en sorte qu'un Diamant taillé à facetes de tous costez, si les facetes estoient fort petites, seroit quasi aussi rond qu'une Perle de mesme grandeur. Les Tourbillons ne sont ronds que de cette maniere-là. Ils ont une infinité de faces en dehors, chacune des quelles porte un autre Tourbillon. Ces faces sont fort inégales; icy elles sont plus grandes, là plus petites. Les plus petites de nostre Tourbillon, par exemple, répondent à la Voye de Lait, & soutiennent tous ces petits Mondes. Que deux Tourbillons qui sont appuyez sur deux faces voisines, laissent quelque vuide entre eux par en bas, comme cela doit arriver tres-souvent, aussi-tost la Nature <UP></UP> qui ménage bien le terrain, vous remplit ce vuide par un petit Tourbillon ou deux, peut-estre par mille, qui n'incommodent point les autres, & ne laissent pas d'estre un ou deux, ou mille Mondes de plus. Ainsi nous pouvons voir beaucoup plus de Mondes que nostre Tourbillon n'a de faces pour en porter <UP></UP>. Je gagerois que quoy que ces petits Mondes n'ayent esté faits que pour estre jettez dans des coins de l'Univers qui fussent demeurez inutiles, quoy qu'ils soient inconnus aux autres Mondes qui les touchent, ils ne laissent pas d'estre fort contents d'eux-mesmes <UP></UP>. Ce sont ceux sans doute dont on ne découvre les petits Soleils qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, & qui sont en une quantité si prodigieuse. Enfin tous ces Tourbillons s'ajustent les uns avec les autres le mieux qu'il est possible, & comme il faut que chacun tourne autour de son Soleil sans changer de place, chacun prend la maniere de tourner, qui est la plus commode & la plus aisée dans la situation où il est. Ils s'engrainent en quelque façon les uns dans les autres comme les rouës d'une Montre, & aident mutuellement leurs mouvemens. Il est pourtant vray qu'ils agissent aussi les uns contre les autres. Chaque Monde, à ce qu'on dit, est comme un <IIM>Ballon</IIM> <UP></UP> qui s'enfle de soy-mesme, & qui s'étendroit, si on le laissoit faire, mais il est aussi-tost repoussé par les Mondes voisins, & il rentre en luy-mesme, aprés quoy il recommence à s'enfler, & ainsi de suite <UP></UP>; & on pretend que les Etoiles Fixes ne nous envoyent cette lumiere tremblante, & ne paroissent briller à reprises, que parce que leurs Tourbillons poussent perpetuellement le nostre, & en sont perpetuellement repoussez.</P097>
chunks.target_manual: <P077>You shew a great deal of Wit, Madam, said I, in raising this doubt, and likewise in not being able to resolve it; for in it self the thing is extreme difficult, and in the manner you conceive it, no answer can be given to it; and he must be a Fool who goes about to find Answers to Objections which are unanswerable. If our Vortex had the form of a Die, it would have six squares or flat faces, and would be far from being round, and upon every of these Squares, might be plac'd a Vortex of the same Figure, but if in stead of these six Square faces, it had twenty, fifty, or a thousand; then might a thousand Vortex's be plac'd upon it, one upon every flat; and you know very well, that the more flat faces any body hath on its outside, <UP>the nearer it approacheth to roundness</UP>, just as a Diamond cut facet-wise on every side, if the facets be very many and little, it will look as round as a Pearl of the same bigness: 'Tis in this manner that the Vortex's are round; they have an infinite number of facets on their outside, and every one of 'em hath upon it another Vortex; these faces are not all equal and alike; but here, some are greater, and there, some less; The least facets of our Vortex, for Example, answer to the Milky way, and sustain all those little Worlds. When two Vortex's are supported by the two next flats on which they stand, if they leave beneath any void space between them, as it must often happen, Nature, <UP>who is an excellent</UP> Huswife, and suffers nothing to be useless, presently fills up this void space with a little Vortex or two, perhaps with a thousand, which never in commode the others, and become one, two, or a thousand Worlds more; so that there may be many more Worlds than our Vortex hath flat faces to bear 'em: <UP>I will lay a good wager</UP>, that tho' these little Worlds were made only to be thrown into the corners of the Universe, which otherwise would have been void and useless; and tho' they are unknown to other Worlds which they touch, yet they are well satisfy'd with their being where they are: These are the little Worlds, whose Suns are not to be discover'd but with a Tellescope, and whose number is prodigious: to conclude, all these Vortex's are joyn'd to one another in so admirable a manner, that every one turns round about his Sun, without changing place; every one hath such a turn as is most easie, and agreeable to its own situation: they take hold of one another, like the wheels of a Watch, and mutually help one anothers motion: And yet 'tis true, that they act contrary to one another. Every World, as some say, is like a Foot-ball, <UP>made of a Bladder </UP>, cover'd with Leather, which sometimes swells of its own accord, and would extend it self, if it were not hindred. But this swelling World being press'd by the next to it, returns to its first Figure; then swells again, and is again deprest; and some affirm that the reason why the fix'd Stars give a twinkling and trembling light, and sometimes seem not to shine at all, is because their Vortex's perpetually push and press our Vortex, and ours again continually repulseth theirs.</P077>
source_segments: la Nature qui ménage bien le terrain
un Ballon
target_segments: Nature, who is an excellent Huswife, and suffers nothing to be useless
a Foot-ball, made of a Bladder, cover'd with Leather
explanations: The French phrase "la Nature qui ménage bien le terrain," which describes Nature as managing resources economically or being thrifty with space, is translated as "Nature, who is an excellent Huswife, and suffers nothing to be useless." This personifies Nature using the specific and culturally resonant image of an "excellent Huswife," a familiar domestic role in 17th-century English society associated with thrift and efficient household management. This adaptation aligns the abstract concept of Nature's economy with target culture norms, making it more concrete and relatable for English readers by invoking a well-understood social figure.

The French term "un Ballon," meaning a general inflated ball, is translated and elaborated as "a Foot-ball, made of a Bladder, cover'd with Leather." Instead of a generic ball, the translator specifies "a Foot-ball" and adds a description of its contemporary construction in England. This replaces a general French term with a reference to a specific object familiar within English popular culture of the period (early forms of football). This domestication makes the simile more vivid and accessible to the target audience by grounding it in a common, culturally specific item.

chunks.source_manual: <P098>J'aime fort toutes ces Idées-là, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. J'aime ces Balons qui s'enflent & se desenflent à chaque moment, & ces Mondes qui se combattent toûjours, & sur tout j'aime à voir comment ce combat fait entre eux un commerce de lumiere, qui asseurément est le seul qu'ils puissent avoir.</P098>
chunks.target_manual: <P078>I am in love with these Fancies, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>; I am pleas'd with these Foot-balls, which swell every moment, and sink again, and with these Worlds, which are continually striving and pushing one another: But above all, I am pleas'd to see how this justling keeps up the trade of Light, which is certainly the only correspondence that is between them.</P078>
source_segments: Marquise
Balons
target_segments: Countess
Foot-balls
explanations: The French source uses the title 'Marquise'. The English translation substitutes this with 'Countess.' While 'Marchioness' would be a more direct hierarchical equivalent, 'Countess' was a very common and familiar title for an aristocratic woman in English society and literature of the period. This change domesticates the character by using a noble rank more readily recognizable and relatable to the English audience, prioritizing target-culture familiarity and accessibility over precise hierarchical rendering of the French title.

The French 'Balons' (meaning balls, or large inflatable balls) is translated as 'Foot-balls.' In the 17th century, footballs in England were commonly made from inflated animal bladders, which would 's'enflent & se desenflent' (swell and deflate) as described in the text. By choosing 'Foot-balls,' a specific and popular object within English culture, the translator adapts Fontenelle's general analogy to be more concrete, vivid, and immediately understandable for the English reader. This grounds the scientific explanation in a familiar everyday experience of the target culture, making the metaphor more domestically resonant.

chunks.source_manual: <P099>Non, non, repris-je, ce n'est pas le seul. Les Mondes voisins nous envoyent quelquefois visiter, & mesme assez magnifiquement. Il nous en vient des Cometes, qui sont toûjours ornées, ou d'une chevelure éclatante, ou d'une barbe venerable, ou d'une queüe majestueuse.</P099> <P100>Ah! quels Deputez dit-elle en riant! On se passeroit bien de leur visite, elle ne sert qu'à faire peur. Ils ne font peur qu'aux <UP></UP> enfants, repliquay-je, à cause de leur équipage extraordinaire, mais <RW>les enfants sont en grand nombre</RW>. Les Cometes ne sont que des Planetes qui appartiennent à un Tourbillon voisin. Elles avoyent leur mouvement vers ses extremitez, mais ce Tourbillon estant peut-estre differemment pressé par ceux qui l'environnent, est plus rond par en haut, & plus plat par en bas, & c'est par en bas qu'il nous regarde. Ces Planetes <UP></UP> qui auront commencé vers le haut à se mouvoir en Cercle, ne prévoyoient pas qu'en bas le Tourbillon leur manqueroit, parce qu'il est là comme écrasé, & pour continuer leur mouvement circulaire, il faut necessairement qu'elles entrent dans un autre Tourbillon, que je suppose qui est le nostre, & qu'elles en coupent les extremitez. Aussi sont-elles toûjours fort élevées à nostre égard, elles marchent beaucoup au dessus de Saturne. Il est necessaire dans nostre Sistême, pour des raisons qui ne sont rien à nostre sujet present, que depuis Saturne jusqu'aux deux extremitez de nostre Tourbillon, il y ait un grand espace vide, & sans Planetes. Nos Ennemis nous reprochent sans cesse inutilité de ce grand espace. Qu'ils ne s'inquietent plus, nous en avons trouvé l'usage, c'est l'apartement des Planetes étrangeres qui entrent dans nostre Monde.</P100>
chunks.target_manual: <P079>No, no, Madam, said I; Light is not their sole commerce; the Neighbouring Worlds sometimes send visits to us, and that in a very magnificent and splendid manner: There come Comets to us from thence, adorn'd with bright shining Hair, Venerable Beards, or Majestick Tails; these said the <IIM>Countess</IIM> are Embassadors, whose Visits may be well spared, since they serve onely to affright us. They scare only Children, said I, with their extraordinary train; but indeed, the number of such Children is now a days very great. Comets are nothing but Planets, which belong to a Neighbouring Vortex, they move towards the out-side of it; but perhaps this Vortex being differently press'd by those Vortex's which encompass it, it is rounder above than it is below, and it is the lower part that is still towards us. These Planets which have begun to move in a Circle above, are not aware that below their Vortex will fail 'em, because it is as it were broken. Therefore to continue the Circular Motion, it is necessary that they enter into another Vortex, which we will suppose is ours, and that they cut through the outsides of it. They appear to us very high, and are much higher than Saturn, and according to our System, it is absolutely necessary they should be so high, for Reasons that signifie nothing to our present subject. From Saturn downwards to the outsides of our Vortex, there is a great void space without any Planets. Our Adversaries often ask us, to what purpose this void space serves? but let them not trouble themselves any more, I have found an use for it. 'Tis the Apartment of those strange Planets, which come into our World.</P079>
source_segments: dit-elle
mais les enfants sont en grand nombre.
Nos Ennemis nous reprochent sans cesse inutilité de ce grand espace.
target_segments: said the Countess
but indeed, the number of such Children is now a days very great.
Our Adversaries often ask us, to what purpose this void space serves?
explanations: The speaker in the original, 'elle' (she), refers to the Marquise, the main female character in Fontenelle's work. The translation identifies her as 'the Countess.' This change in aristocratic title from 'Marquise' (a specific French noble rank) to 'Countess' (a different, though also high, noble rank) adapts the character to a title that might have been perceived by the translator as more familiar, conventional, or relatable for an English audience of the late 17th century. This domesticates a specific character detail by substituting it with one more aligned with English social referents.

The original French 'mais les enfants sont en grand nombre' (literally, 'but children are in great number' or 'but children are numerous') is a general, timeless observation about credulity. The English translation adds the phrase 'now a days' and the intensifier 'indeed', rendering it as 'but indeed, the number of such Children is now a days very great.' This addition temporally grounds the statement, making it a comment on the translator's (and thus the target readers') contemporary period. This localization in time is a form of domestication, adapting a general philosophical observation to make it resonate more directly and urgently with the target culture's immediate social context and perceived conditions.

The French original describes the intellectual opponents as 'Nos Ennemis nous reprochent sans cesse inutilité de ce grand espace' (Our Enemies/Adversaries ceaselessly reproach us for the uselessness of this great space), which is a direct and strongly phrased accusation. The English translation recasts this confrontation as 'Our Adversaries often ask us, to what purpose this void space serves?'. This alteration significantly softens the tone of the intellectual disagreement, changing a forceful, repeated criticism about 'uselessness' into a more indirect, interrogative challenge about 'purpose.' This toning down of polemical language is a domestication strategy, potentially adapting the style of discourse to what the translator perceived as more fitting for the English literary or popular science context, or to make the debate appear more civil to the target audience.

chunks.source_manual: <P101>J'entends, dit-elle. <NCP></NCP>. Nous ne les laissons pas entrer jusque dans le cœur de nostre Tourbillon, & avec nos Planetes, nous les recevons comme le Grand Seigneur reçoit les Ambassadeurs qu'on luy envoye. Il ne leur fait pas l'honneur de les loger à Constantinople, mais seulement dans un Fauxbourg de la Ville. <IIM>Nous avons encore cela de commun avec les Ottomans</IIM>, repris-je, qu'ils reçoivent des Ambassadeurs sans en renvoyer, & que nous ne renvoyons point de nos Planetes aux Mondes voisins.</P101>
chunks.target_manual: <P080>I understand you, says she, <UP>we do not suffer them to come</UP> into the heart of our Vortex, among our own Planets, but we receive them as the Grand Signior doth the Embassadours that are sent to him; he will not shew them so much respect as to let 'em Lodge in Constantinople, but Quarters 'em in one of the Suburbs of the City: Madam, said I, we, and the Ottomans agree likewise in this, that as they receive Embassadours, but never send any, so we never send any of our Planets into the Worlds that are next us.</P080>
source_segments: repris-je
target_segments: Madam, said I
explanations: The French source text uses "repris-je" (I replied/I resumed), which is a simple narrative attribution of speech. The English translation renders this as "Madam, said I," adding the explicit vocative "Madam" to address the Marquise. This addition is an instance of domestication because it adapts the conversational style to align with English social and linguistic norms of the period (late 17th/early 18th century). By inserting "Madam," the translator makes the philosopher's manner of addressing the Marquise conform more directly to English expectations of politeness, formality, and deference within a hierarchical social interaction, thus making the dialogue resonate more naturally with the target culture's conventions but subtly altering the original French interactional nuance.

chunks.source_manual: <P102>A en juger par toutes ces choses-là, repliqua-t-elle, <UP></UP>, nous sommes bien fiers. Cependant je ne sçais pas trop encore ce que j'en dois croire. Ces Planetes étrangeres ont un air bien menaçant avec leurs queües & leurs barbes, & peut-estre on nous les envoye pour nous insulter, au lieu que les nostres, qui ne sont pas faites de la mesme maniere, ne seroient pas si propres à se faire craindre, quand elles iroient dans les autres Mondes.</P102>
chunks.target_manual: <P081>By this, says she, it appears that we are very proud, however I do not yet very well know what I am to believe. These forreign Planets with thei Tails and their Beards have a terrible Countenance, it may be they are sent to affront us; but ours that are of another make, if they should get into other Worlds, are not so proper to make people afraid.</P081>
source_segments: ont un air bien menaçant
target_segments: have a terrible Countenance
explanations: The French phrase "ont un air bien menaçant," which translates to "have a very threatening look/aspect," is rendered in English as "have a terrible Countenance." While "terrible" corresponds to the intensity of "bien menaçant" (very threatening/formidable), the choice of "Countenance" (face, facial expression) for the French "Air" (look, aspect, mien) is a significant shift. This translation lends a more vivid, and arguably more anthropomorphic, quality to the "Planetes étrangeres" (foreign planets/comets, as implied by their "Tails and their Beards"). This choice appears to be a deliberate adaptation to align with English literary and popular conventions of the late 17th century. During this period, celestial phenomena, particularly comets, were often described using strong, dramatic, and sometimes personified imagery (e.g., in contemporary English works like Milton's *Paradise Lost*). The phrase "terrible countenance" was an existing English expression used to describe formidable or dreadful appearances. By employing this phrase, the translator makes the Marquise's fearful description more resonant with target culture stylistic norms for such subjects, thereby domesticating the original French expression to make it more familiar and impactful for the English readership.

chunks.source_manual: <P103>Les queües & les barbes, répondis-je, ne sont que de pures apparences. <UP></UP>. Les Planetes étrangeres ne different en rien des nostres, mais en entrant dans nostre Tourbillon, elles prennent la queüe ou la barbe par une certaine sorte d'illumination qu'elles reçoivent du Soleil, & qui entre nous n'a pas encore esté trop bien expliquée; mais toûjours on est seur qu'il ne s'agit que d'une espece d'illumination <UP></UP>; on la devinera quand on pourra. Je voudrois donc bien, reprit-elle, que nostre Saturne allast prendre une queuë ou une barbe dans quelqu'autre Tourbillon, & y répandre l'effroy, & qu'en suite ayant mis bas cet <IIM>accompagnement</IIM> terrible, il revint se ranger icy avec les autres Planetes à ses fonctions ordinaires. Il vaut mieux pour luy, répondis-je, qu'il ne sorte point de nostre Tourbillon. Je vous ay dit le choc qui se fait à l'endroit où deux Tourbillons se poussent & se repoussent l'un l'autre; je croy que dans ce pas là une pauvre Planete est agitée assez rudement, & que ses habitans ne s'en portent pas mieux. Nous croyons nous autres estre bien malheureux quand il nous paroist une Comete; c'est la Comete elle-même qui est bien malheureuse. Je ne le crois point, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, elle nous apporte tous ses habitans en bonne santé. Rien n'est si divertissant que de changer ainsi de Tourbillon. Nous qui ne sortons jamais du nostre, nous menons une vie assez ennuyeuse. Si les habitans d'une Comete ont assez d'esprit pour prévoir le temps de leur passage dans nostre Monde, ceux qui ont déja fait le voyage, annoncent aux autres par avance ce qu'ils y verront. Vous découvrirez bien-tost une Planete qui a un grand Anneau autour d'elle, disent-ils peut-estre, en parlant de Saturne. Vous en verrez une autre qui en a quatre petites qui la suivent. Peut-estre mesme y a-t-il des gens destinés à observer le moment où ils entrent dans nostre Monde, & qui crient aussi-tost, Nouveau Soleil, Nouveau Soleil, comme ces Matelots qui crient, Terre, Terre. <UP></UP>.</P103>
chunks.target_manual: <P082>Their Beards and their Tails Madam, said I, are not real, they are <UP>Phaenomena</UP>, and but meer Appearances. These forreign Planets differ in nothing from ours, but entring into our Vortex, they seem to us to have Tails or Beards, by a certain sort of Illumination which they receive from the Sun, and which hath not been yet well explain'd. But certain it is, that 'tis but a kind of illumination, and when I am able I will tell you how 'tis done. I wish then, says she, that our Saturn would go take a Tail or a Beard in another Vortex, and affright all the Inhabitants of it. That done, I would have him come back again, leaving his terrible <IIM>Accoutrements</IIM> behind him, and taking his usual place amongst our other Planets, fall to his ordinary business. 'Tis better for him, said I, not to go out of our Vortex. I have told you how rude and violent the Shock is, when two Vortex's justle one another, a poor Planet must needs be terribly shaken, and its Inhabitants in no better condition. We think our selves very unhappy when a Comet appears, but 'tis the Comet that is in an ill case. I do not believe that, say she, it brings all its Inhabitants with it in very good health; there can be nothing so diverting as to change Vortex's. We that never go out of our own, lead but a dull Life; if the Inhabitants of a Comet had but the wit to foresee the time when they are to come into our world, they that had already made the Voyage, would tell their Neighbours beforehand what they should see, they would tell them, that they would discover a Planet with a great Ring about it, meaning our Saturn, they would also say, you shall see another Planet which hath four little ones to wait on it; and perhaps some of them, resolv'd to observe the very Moment of their entring into our World, would presently cry out A New Sun, a New Sun, as Sailors use to cry Land, Land.</P082>
source_segments: répondis-je
on la devinera quand on pourra.
est bien malheureuse
aux autres
target_segments: Madam, said I
and when I am able I will tell you how 'tis done.
is in an ill case
their Neighbours
explanations: The English translation inserts the honorific "Madam" when rendering the philosopher's speech ('répondis-je' / 'said I'). This addition adapts the dialogue to English conversational norms of the period, where direct address with honorifics like "Madam" was common in polite discourse, making the interaction pattern more familiar to an English reader and conforming the text to target culture etiquette.

The French "on la devinera quand on pourra" (literally "one will guess it when one will be able to," implying a collective, future discovery) expresses an impersonal and somewhat uncertain outlook on future understanding. The English translation transforms this into a personal promise from the philosopher-narrator: "and when I am able I will tell you how 'tis done." This domesticates the original by shifting the presentation of scientific knowledge from a general, evolving process to a more direct, personalized, and authoritative didactic commitment by the narrator to the listener. This makes the scientific popularizer seem more like a personal tutor, aligning with a potentially more direct instructional style in the target culture.

The French "est bien malheureuse" (is very unhappy/unfortunate) is a straightforward description. The English translation replaces this with the idiomatic expression "is in an ill case," meaning to be in a bad situation or predicament. This substitution of a general French adjective with a specific, colloquial English idiom of the period makes the phrasing more natural and familiar to an English reader, thus domesticating the text by adapting it to target language idiomatic norms.

The French "aux autres" (to the others) is a general term for the recipients of the information. The English translation uses "their Neighbours." While "neighbours" can broadly mean "others," it more specifically evokes a sense of community and proximity, a familiar terrestrial social concept. Applying this to the inhabitants of a comet domesticates the original by framing their social interactions in terms more recognizable and relatable to the target culture, potentially reducing the alienness of the imagined extraterrestrial society.

chunks.source_manual: <P104>Il ne faut donc plus songer, luy dis-je, à vous donner de la pitié pour les habitans d'une Comète, mais j'espere du moins que vous plaindrez ceux qui vivent dans un Tourbillon dont le Soleil vient à s'éteindre, & <SC>qui demeurent dans une nuit éternelle</SC>. Quoi? s'écria-t-elle, des Soleils s'éteignent? Oüi, sans doute, répondis-je. Les Anciens ont vû dans le Ciel des Etoiles fixes que nous n'y voyons plus. Ces Soleils ont perdu leur lumiere; grande desolation assurément dans tout le Tourbillon; mortalité generale sur toutes les Planetes; car que faire sans Soleil? Cette idée est trop funeste, reprit-elle. N'y auroit-il pas moyen de me l'épargner? Je vous diray si vous voulez, répondis-je, ce que disent de fort habiles gens, que les Etoiles fixes qui ont disparu ne se sont pas pour cela éteintes, que ce sont des Soleils qui ne le sont qu'à demy, c'est à dire qui ont <IIM>une moitié obscure</IIM>, & l'autre lumineuse; que comme ils tournent sur eux-mesmes, tantost ils nous presentent la moitié lumineuse, & qu'alors nous ne les voyons, tantost la moitié obscure, & qu'alors nous ne les voyons plus. Je prendray bien pour vous obliger cette opinion là, qui est plus douce que l'autre, mais je ne puis la prendre qu'à l'égard de certaines Etoiles qui ont des temps reglez pour paroître & pour disparoistre, ainsi qu'on a commencé à s'en apercevoir, autrement les demy Soleils ne peuvent pas subsister. Mais que dirons-nous des Etoiles qui disparoissent & ne se remontrent pas aprés le temps pendant lequel elles auroient dû assurément achever de tourner sur elles-mesmes? Vous estes trop équitable pour vouloir m'obliger à croire que ce soient des demy Soleils: cependant je feray encore un effort en vostre faveur. Ces Soleils ne se seront pas éteints, ils se seront seulement enfoncez dans la profondeur immense du Ciel, & nous ne pourrons plus les voir. En ce cas le Tourbillon aura suivy son Soleil, & tout s'y portera bien. Il est vray que la plus grande partie des Etoiles fixes n'ont pas ce mouvement par lequel elles s'éloignent de nous, car en d'autres temps elles devroient s'en rapprocher, & nous les verrions tantost plus grandes, tantost plus petites, ce qui n'arrive pas. Mais nous supposerons qu'il n'y a que quelques petits Tourbillons plus legers & plus agiles qui se glissent entre les autres, & font de certains tours, au bout desquels ils reviennent, tandis que le gros des Tourbillons demeure immobile; mais voicy un étrange malheur, il y a des Etoiles fixes qui viennent se montrer à nous, qui passent beaucoup de temps à ne faire que paroistre & disparoistre, & enfin disparoissent entierement, des demi Soleils reparoîtroient dans des temps reglez. Des Soleils qui s'enfonceroient dans le Ciel ne disparoistroient qu'une fois pour ne reparoistre de longtemps. Prenez vostre resolution, Madame, avec courage; il faut que ces Etoiles soient des Soleils qui s'obscurcissent assez pour cesser d'estre visibles à nos yeux, & en suite se rallument, & à la fin s'éteignent tout à fait. Comment un Soleil peut-il s'obscurcir & s'éteindre, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, luy qui est en luy-mesme une source de lumiere? Le plus aisément du Monde, selon Descartes, répondis-je, nostre Soleil a des tâches. Que ce soient ou des écumes, des broüillards, ou tout ce qu'il vous plaira, ces taches peuvent s'épaissir, se mettre plusieurs ensemble, s'accrocher les unes aux autres, en suite elles iront jusqu'à former autour du Soleil une croûte qui s'augmentera toujours, & adieu le Soleil <UP></UP>. Nous l'avons déja même échepée belle, dit-on. Le Soleil a esté tres-pasle pendant des années entieres, pendant celle, par exemple, qui suivit la mort de Cesar. C'estoit la croûte qui commençoit à se faire, la force du Soleil la rompit & la dissipa; mais si elle eust continué, nous estions perdus. Vous me faites trembler, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Presentement que je sçay les consequences de la pâleur du Soleil, je crois qu'au lieu d'aller voir les matins à mon miroir si je ne suis point pasle, j'iray voir au Ciel si le Soleil ne l'est point luy même. Ah! Madame, répondis-je, rassurez-vous, il faut du temps pour ruiner un Monde. Mais enfin, dit-elle, il ne faut que du temps? Je vous l'avouë, repris-je: Toute cette masse immense de matiere qui compose l'Univers est dans un mouvement perpétuel, dont aucune de ses parties n'est entierement exempte; & dés qu'il y a du mouvement quelque part, ne vous y fiez point, il faut qu'il arrive des changemens: soit lents, soit prompts, mais toujours dans des temps proportionnez à l'effet. Les Anciens estoient <IIM>plaisans</IIM> de s'imaginer que les Corps celestes étoient de nature à ne changer jamais, parce qu'ils ne les avoyent pas encore vû changer. <IIM>Avoyent-ils eu le loisir de s'en assurer par l'experience?</IIM> Les Anciens étoient jeunes auprés de nous. Si les Roses qui ne durent qu'un jour faisoient des Histoires, & se laissoient des Memoires les unes aux autres, les premieres auroient fait le portrait de leur Jardinier d'une certaine façon, & de plus de quinze mille áges de Rose, les autres qui l'auroient encore laissé à celles qui les devoyent suivre, n'y auroient rien changé. Sur cela elles diroient, nous avons toûjours vû le mesme Jardinier <UP></UP>, de memoire de Rose on n'a vû que luy, il a toûjours esté fait comme il est, assurément il ne meurt point comme nous, il ne change seulement pas. Le raisonnement des Roses seroit-il bon? Il auroit pourtant plus de fondement que celuy que faisoient les Anciens sur les Corps celestes; & quand même il ne seroit arrivé aucun changement dans les Cieux jusqu'à aujourd'huy, quand ils paroistroient marquer qu'ils seroient faits pour durer toûjours sans aucune alteration, je ne les en croirois pas encore, j'attendrois une plus longue experience. Devons-nous établir nostre durée, qui n'est que d'un instant, pour la mesure de quelque-autre? Seroit-ce à dire que ce qui auroit duré cent mille fois plus que nous, dût toûjours durer? On n'est pas si aisément éternel. Il faudroit qu'une chose eût passé bien des âges d'homme mis à bout pour commencer à donner quelque signe d'immortalité. Vrayment, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je voy les Mondes bien éloignez d'y pouvoir pretendre. Je ne leur ferois seulement pas l'honneur de les comparer à ce Jardinier qui dure tant à l'égard des Roses; ils ne sont que comme les Roses mêmes qui naissent & qui meurent dans un Jardin les unes aprés les autres; car je m'attens bien que s'il disparoist des Etoiles anciennes, il en paroist de nouvelles, il faut que l'espece se repare. Il n'est pas à craindre qu'elle perisse, répondis-je. Les uns vous diront que ce ne sont que des Soleils qui se rapprochent de nous aprés avoir esté long- temps perdus pour nous dans la profondeur du Ciel. D'autres vous diront que ce sont des Soleils qui se sont démeslez de cette croûte obscure qui commençoit à les environner. Je croy aisément que tout cela peut estre, mais je croy aussi que l'Univers peut avoir esté fait de sorte qu'il s'y formera de temps en temps des Soleils nouveaux. Pourquoy la matiere propre à faire un Soleil ne pourra-t'elle pas, aprés avoir esté dispersée en plusieurs endroits différens, se ramasser à la longue en un certain lieu, & y jetter les fondemens d'un nouveau Monde? J'ay d'autant plus d'inclination à croire ces nouvelles productions, qu'elles répondent mieux à la haute idée que j'ay des ouvrages de la Nature. N'auroit-elle le secret que de faire naistre & mourir des herbes ou des plantes par une revolution continuelle? Je suis persuadé, & vous l'estes déja aussi, qu'elle pratique ce même secret sur les Mondes, & qu'il ne luy en coûte pas davantage. De bonne foy, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je trouve à present les Mondes, les Cieux, & les Corps celestes si sujets au changement, que m'en voila tout à fait revenuë. Revenons encore mieux, si vous m'en croyez, repliquay-je, n'en parlons plus, aussi bien vous voila arrivée à la derniere voûte des Cieux; & pour vous dire s'il y a encore des Etoiles au delà, il faudroit estre plus habile que je ne suis. Mettez-y encore des Mondes, n'y en mettez pas, cela dépend de vous. C'est proprement l'Empire des Philosophes que ces grands païs invisibles qui peuvent estre ou n'estre pas si on veut, ou estre tels que l'on veut, il me suffit d'avoir mené vôtre esprit aussi loin que vont vos yeux.</P104>
chunks.target_manual: <P083>You have no reason then, said I, to pity the Inhabitants of a Comet, yet I suppose you will think their Condition lamentable, who inhabit a Vortex whose Sun comes in time to be quite extinguished, and consequently live in Eternal Night. How? cry'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, can Suns be put out? Yes, without doubt said I, for People some thousand years ago saw fix'd Stars in the Sky, which are now no more to be seen; these were Suns which have lost their Light, and certainly there must be strange Desolation in their Vortex's, and a general Mortality over all the Planets, for what can People do without a Sun? This is a dismal Fancy, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I would not if I could help it, let it come into my head. I will tell you if you please, I reply'd, what in this particular is the Opinion of Learned Astronomers. They think that the fix'd Stars which have disappear'd, are not quite extinguish'd, but that they are <UP>half Suns</UP>, that is, they have one half Dark, and the other half Light, and turning round upon their own Axis or Centre, they sometimes shew us their Light side, and afterwards turning to us their Dark side, we see them no more. To oblige you Madam, I will be of this Opinion, because it is not so harsh as the other, but I cannot make it good, but in relation to some certain Stars, because as some have lately observed, those Stars have their Regulated times of appearing, and disappearing, otherwise there could be no such thing as half Suns. But what shall we say of Stars, which totally disappear, and never shew themselves again after they have finish'd their Course of turning round upon their own Axis? you are too just Madam to oblige me to believe that such Stars are half Suns. However I will try once more what I can do in favour of your Opinion; the Suns are not extinct, they are only sunk so low into the immense depth of Heaven, that we cannot possibly see them, in this Case the Vortex follows his Sun and all's well again. 'Tis true, that the greatest part of the fix'd Stars have not this motion, by which they remove themselves so far from us, because at other times they might return again nearer to us, and we should see them sometimes greater, and sometimes less, which never happens. But we will suppose that none but the Little, Light, and most Active Vortex's which slip between the others make certain voyages, after which they return again, while the main body of Vortex's remain unmov'd. 'Tis likewise very strange that some fix'd Stars shew themselves to us, spending a great deal of time in appearing, and disappearing, and at last, totally and entirely disappear. Half Suns would appear again at their set and regulated time. Now Madam, boldly declare your Opinion; Must not these Stars of necessity be Suns which are so much darkned as not to be visible to us, yet afterwards shine again, and at last are wholly extinct? How can a Sun said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, be darkned, and quite extinguish'd, when it is in its own Nature a Fountain of Light? It may be done Madam, said I, with all the ease in the world, if Desc�rtes Opinion be true, that our Sun hath Spots; now whether these Spots be Scum or thick Mists, or what you please, they may thicken and unite, till at last they cover the Sun with a Crust, which daily grows thicker, and then Farewell Sun. We have hitherto scap'd pretty well; but 'tis said, that the Sun for some whole years together hath look'd very pale; for Example, the year after Caesar's death; it was this Crust that then began to grow, but the force of the Sun broke and dissipated it; had it continued, we had been all lost People. You make me tremble, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>; and now I know the fatal consequences of the Sun's paleness, I believe, instead of going every morning to my Glass, to see how I look, I shall cast my Eyes up to Heaven, to see whether or no the Sun looks pale. Oh, Madam, said I, there is a great deal of time required to ruine a World. Grant it, said she, yet 'tis but time that is required. I confess it, said I; all this immense mass of Matter that composes the Universe, is in perpetual motion, no part of it excepted; and since every part is moved, you may be sure that changes must happen sooner or later; but still in times proportioned to the Effect. The Ancients were <UP>pleasant Gentlemen</UP>, to imagine that the celestial Bodies were in their own nature unchangeable, because they observed no change in them; but they did not live long enough to confirm their opinion by their own experience; they were Boys in comparison of us. <UP>Give me leave, Madam, to explain my self by an Allegory</UP>: If Roses, which last but a day, could write Histories, and leave Memoirs one to another; and if the first Rose should draw an exact Picture of their Gardiner, and after fifteen thousand Rose-Ages, it should be left to other Roses, and so left still to those that should succeed, without any change in it; should the Roses hereupon say, we have every day seen the same Gardiner, and in the memory of Roses, none ever saw any Gardiner but this; he is still the same he was, and therefore certainly he will never die, as we do; for there is no change at all in him. Would not these Roses, Madam, talk very foolishly? and yet there would be more reason in their discourse, than there was in what the Ancients said concerning celestial Bodies; and tho' even to this very day there should appear no visible change in the Heavens, and the matter of which they are made, should have all the signs of an eternal duration without any change; yet I would not believe 'em unchangeable, till I had the experience of many more Ages. Ought we, who last but a moment, make our continuance the measure of any other things duration; 'tis not so easie a matter to be eternal. To have lasted many Ages of Men, one after another, is no sign of Immortality. Truly, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I find the Worlds are far from being able to pretend to it; I will not do 'em so much honour, as to ompare 'em to the Gardiner that lived so much longer than the Roses: I begin to think 'em like the Roses themselves, which blow one day, and die the next: For now I understand, that if old Stars disappear, new ones will come in their room, because every species must preserve it self. No species, Madam, said I, can totally perish; some perhaps will tell you, that such new Stars are Suns, which return to our sight again, after they have been a long time hid from us, in the profundity of Heaven: Others may tell you, they are Suns cleared from that thick crust, which once covered them: If I should think all this possible, yet I likewise believe that the Universe may be framed in such a manner, that from time to time it may produce new Suns; why may not that matter which is proper to make a Sun, be dispers'd here and there, and gather it self again at long run, into one certain place, and lay the foundation of a new World? I am very much inclin'd to believe such new productions, because they suit with that glorious and admirable Idea which I have of the works of Nature. Can we think that wise Nature knows no more than the secret of making Herbs and Plants live and die by a continual revolution? I am verily perswaded, and are not you so too, Madam? that Nature, without much cost or pains can put the same secret in practice, upon the Worlds. I now find, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, the Worlds, the Heaven, and celestial Bodies so subject to change, that I am come to my self again. To come the better again to our selves, I reply'd, let us say no more of these Matters. We are arrived at the very roof and top of all the Heavens; and to tell you whether there be any Stars beyond it, you must have an abler Man than I am; you may place Worlds there, or no Worlds, as you please: 'Tis the Philosopher's Empire to describe those vast invisible Countries, which are, and are not, or are such as he pleases to make 'em: It is enough for me, to have carried your mind as far as you can see with your Eyes.</P083>

explanations: The French text refers to the female interlocutor using the title "la Marquise." The English translation consistently changes this specific aristocratic title to "the Countess." This substitution adapts the character's title to a different, albeit also noble, rank that may have been more common or relatable for an English audience of the late 17th century, thereby domesticating the social specificity of the original French character.

The French "Les Anciens estoient plaisans" (The Ancients were amusing/droll) is rendered as "The Ancients were pleasant Gentlemen." The addition of "Gentlemen," an English social category, domesticates the characterization of the Ancients by framing them in terms familiar to the target culture, subtly altering the tone of the philosopher's critique from merely "amusing" to a more socially placed "pleasant Gentlemen."

The French phrase "échepée belle" (to have a narrow escape) is rendered more mildly as "scap'd pretty well." More significantly, the qualifier "dit-on" ("it is said"), which attributes the idea to common report, is entirely omitted in the English translation. This makes the philosopher's statement more direct and assertive, removing the original's nuance of reported information, a transformation that aligns the text with a potentially preferred directness in the target culture's popular science discourse.

The French text transitions directly into the rose analogy ("Si les Roses..."). The English translation introduces this analogy with the added preface "Give me leave, Madam, to explain my self by an Allegory:". This addition explicitly labels the rhetorical device and adopts a formal, polite mode of address not present in the original. This domestication makes the text's structure more overt and aligns it with English discursive conventions of the period, potentially aiming for greater clarity or politeness for the target audience.

The French "C'est proprement l'Empire des Philosophes que ces grands païs invisibles" identifies "ces grands païs invisibles" (these great invisible countries) *as* the "Empire of Philosophers," emphasizing their dominion. The English translation "'Tis the Philosopher's Empire to describe..." shifts the meaning, stating that the philosophers' empire consists in the *act of describing* these countries. This conceptual adaptation reinterprets "Empire" from a realm of control to a field of intellectual activity, a domestication that might make the philosophers' role more palatable or align with different cultural valuations of philosophical endeavor in the target culture.

chunks.source_manual: <P105>Quoi, s'écria-t-elle, j'ay dans la teste tout le systeme de l'Univers! Je suis sçavante! Oüy, repliquay-je, vous l'estes assez raisonnablement, & vous l'estes avec la commodité de pouvoir ne rien croire de tout ce que je vous ay dit dés que l'envie vous en prendra. Je vous demande seulement pour recompense de mes peines de ne voir jamais le Soleil, ny le Ciel, ny les Etoiles, sans songer à moy.</P105>
chunks.target_manual: <P084>Well, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I have now in my Head, the System of the Universe: How learned am I become? Indeed, Madam, said I, you are pretty knowing, and you are so with the advantage of believing, or not believing any thing I have said: For all my pains, I only beg this favour, that when ever you see the Sun, the Heaven, or the Stars, you will think of me.</P084>
source_segments: elle
Quoi, s'écria
target_segments: the Countess
Well, says
explanations: The original French work features a 'Marquise' as the female interlocutor. The pronoun 'elle' (she) in the French text (from 's'écria-t-elle') refers to this Marquise. The English translation explicitly names this character 'the Countess' (in 'says the Countess'). This change substitutes a French aristocratic title with 'Countess,' an English aristocratic title. This domesticates the character by recasting her within a framework more familiar to the English reader of the period, aligning her with target culture norms of nobility, even though 'Marquise' or 'Marchioness' exist in English.

The French phrase 'Quoi, s'écria' (What! [she] cried/exclaimed) indicates a strong and spontaneous emotional reaction of surprise. The English translation 'Well, says' significantly tones down this expressiveness. 'Well' is a much milder interjection than 'Quoi!', and 'says' is a neutral reporting verb, lacking the emotive force of 's'écria'. This alteration makes the character's reaction more subdued, potentially aligning her speech style with perceived English norms of genteel and less effusive expression for a noblewoman in that period, thus domesticating the portrayal of her emotion.

target_segments: FINIS.
explanations: The French source uses 'FIN' (French for 'End') to mark the conclusion of the work. The English translation uses 'FINIS.', which is Latin for 'End'. During the late 17th and 18th centuries, it was a common convention in English printed books to use the Latin term 'FINIS' to signify the end. This translation domesticates the original French textual convention by replacing it with a typographic and paratextual convention familiar and standard within the target English literary and publishing culture of the period, thereby making the book's presentation conform to the expectations of an English readership.
